body: Are you talking about the weight decay? which file are you looking at?

@Godricly  You can see train_model.py in example/image-classification at this line :
 model = mx.model.FeedForward(
        ctx                = devs,
        symbol             = network,
        num_epoch          = args.num_epochs,
        learning_rate      = args.lr,
        momentum           = 0.9,
        wd                 = 0.00001,
        initializer        = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34),
        **model_args)

@tornadomeet For ARM, i think Eigen is a good choice. If we want to get better performance, we can't use a genneral implement, right? General implement usally means just ok performance.

@hjk41 so right now, i will integrate MKL DNN as a start to improve performance on x86 cpus.

I did check that. U made a typo on the issue title which is misleading. It should be the weight decay parameter. U can find out how it is used in [python/mxnet/optimizer.py](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py).

@xmchen1987 Do you consider integration of NNPACK? It has some benefits vs MKL DNN:
1. NNPACK implements faster algorithm for convolutional layers based on Winograd transforms
2. NNPACK is not restricted to x86-64
3. NNPACK is open-source
@Maratyszcza i prefer NNPACK personal.

Thanks you all,

    input_data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="data")
   ......... .........

    shuffle=True,
    path_imgrec="Datasets/train.rec",
    mean_img="Datasets/mean.bin",

    path_imgrec="Datasets/val.rec",
    mean_img="Datasets/mean.bin",

    rand_mirror = False,
    data_shape  = data_shape,
    batch_size  = batch_size,
    preprocess_threads=1)

num_epoch = 100

model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    ctx = mx.gpu(0),      # Run on GPU 0
    symbol = cellnet,         # Use the network we just defined
    num_epoch = 10,       # Train for 10 epochs
    learning_rate = 0.1,  # Learning rate
    momentum = 0.9,       # Momentum for SGD with momentum
    wd = 0.00001)         # Weight decay for regularization
model.fit(
    X=train_iter,  # Training data set
    eval_data=test_iter,  # Testing data set. MXNet computes scores on test set every epoch
    batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 200))  # Logging module to print out progress

@Godricly Thank you ,I got it
this pr https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/3005 enables multi dimensional labels. Use --pack_label=1 to pack label together with data

I think both NNPACK and MKL DNN are good libraries, we can support both if we have enough resource, just like we support both OpenBLAS and MKL. As to which library support to implement first, I am fine with either way. 

I will leave it to @xmchen1987 to decide which library to use first. Whatever he chooses to integrate first, it is a good contribution to mxnet community. If anyone else would like to join the effort and integrate NNPACK, he is more than welcome.

Hi, can you improve this roi operator with DType support? I looked into your .cc and .cu file. And I saw you using DType template to compute. However the .h file is only considering real_t type. Is there any trouble around here doing DType stuff?

@Maratyszcza I agree. NNPACK is a promising library, it implements latest algorithm for convolution. compared with MKL DNN, it may be faster. 

@hjk41 I think we can support both of them, and i choose NNPACK as a start.

The problem is we change pooling shape recently. We will release a new
version code of Deepmark soon.

A quick fix is: Add padding 1 to the pooling branch in last tower of each
branch

>  think it depends on how the cifar example uses the library. If it does not use matrix multiplication much, you will not see much speedup when using multiple threads. I think for Cifar, most of the time should be spent on the convolution layers? Then it comes to how convolution is implemented on CPU

But for prediction, each prediction from different thread should be independent. 
Prediction in multiple threads are really needed.

@pluskid @freddycct

New LSTM unit example:

```
def lstm(num_hidden, indata, mask, prev_state, param, seqidx, layeridx, dropout=0.):
    """LSTM Unit symbol"""
    i2h = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=indata,
                                weight=param.i2h_weight,
                                bias=param.i2h_bias,
                                num_hidden=num_hidden * 4,
                                name="t%d_l%d_i2h" % (seqidx, layeridx))
    h2h = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=prev_state.h,
                                weight=param.h2h_weight,
                                bias=param.h2h_bias,
                                num_hidden=num_hidden * 4,
                                name="t%d_l%d_h2h" % (seqidx, layeridx))
    gates = i2h + h2h
    slice_gates = mx.sym.SliceChannel(gates, num_outputs=4,
                                      name="t%d_l%d_slice" % (seqidx, layeridx))
    in_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[0], act_type="sigmoid")
    in_transform = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[1], act_type="tanh")
    forget_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[2], act_type="sigmoid")
    out_gate = mx.sym.Activation(slice_gates[3], act_type="sigmoid")
    next_c = (forget_gate * prev_state.c) + (in_gate * in_transform)
    next_h = out_gate * mx.sym.Activation(next_c, act_type="tanh")
    # dropout the hidden h
    next_h = mx.sym.Dropout(next_h, p=dropout)
    # mask out the output
    next_c = mx.sym.element_mask(next_c, mask)
    next_h = mx.sym.element_mask(next_h, mask)
    return LSTMState(c=next_c, h=next_h)
```

Do you think it is enough?

I'm having exactly same problem with windows 10 64bit, Visual Studio 2013, CUDA 8.0 RC, CUDNN5, built from source as of 8/10. Has anyone figured out what is the root cause of this issue?

It appears NDArray assignment by numerical value doesn't work, but setting by numpy array is fine, as in this short example.

```
import mxnet
arr = mxnet.ndarray.empty( (2,2), mxnet.gpu(0) )
arr[:] = 1.
arr.asnumpy()
array([[ 0.,  0.],
       [ 0.,  0.]], dtype=float32)
import numpy
arr[:] = numpy.ones((2,2))
arr.asnumpy()
array([[ 1.,  1.],
       [ 1.,  1.]], dtype=float32)

```

Also, when I built mxnet debug version the gpu is working fine, e.g. mnist example converges quickly.

@xmchen1987 @tornadomeet: An argument for [Intel DAAL](https://github.com/01org/daal) over NNPACK: 
1. NNPACK [doesn't support Windows](https://github.com/Maratyszcza/NNPACK/issues/25)
2. Intel DAAL will receive vastly more developer support over the long run than NNPACK, and will eventually be the fastest implementation on standard deployment hardware (ie. Xeon CPU's). 
3. Intel DAAL is also open source, like NNPACK

Agreed that it would be nice to have both in the long run.

_Correction_: the implementation of the DNN layers in Intel DAAL are not open source, as they come from MKL. The relevant pieces of MKL are included in the DAAL binaries, which are very permisively licensed (Apache License 2.0).
Also, this issue is relevant for this discussion: #2435

are you sure? I and another guy both met the problem. Here is the symbol we used:

```
def get_mine():
    data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')

    conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv1', data=data , num_filter=20, pad=(0,0), kernel=(5,5), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
    pool1 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool1', data=conv1 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
    conv2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(name='conv2', data=pool1 , num_filter=50, pad=(0,0), kernel=(5,5), stride=(1,1), no_bias=False)
    pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(name='pool2', data=conv2 , pad=(0,0), kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2), pool_type='max')
    flatten_0=mx.symbol.Flatten(name='flatten_0', data=pool2)
    ip1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='ip1', data=flatten_0 , num_hidden=500, no_bias=False)
    relu1 = mx.symbol.Activation(name='relu1', data=ip1 , act_type='relu')
    ip2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='ip2', data=relu1 , num_hidden=10, no_bias=False)
    softmax = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(name='softmax', data=ip2 )

    return softmax;
```
@sbodenstein Intel DAAL is irrelevant. It is a high-level library, similar to MxNet. For the actual implementation of high-intensity operations, it leverages Intel MKL DNN functions.

Haha. I know why. In get_mine(), activation layers between conv and pool are missed. Then the original learning rate could be too big for the network to train. However, if you add activ layers, then training is fine.
thanks
Ok. then it's just network difference. Thanks
Got it, I can write the epoch callback function to eval the acc, @VoVAllen, @eric-haibin-lin ,thanks for help!

I think what @heyitskoma want is the support of sparse matrix as input. It would be nice to support that, because even though we mainly use Embedding to process high cardinality features, occasionally we use MXNet for large scale linear model.

@sbodenstein Thank you! I am not quite sure which will be better, so maybe we can discuss with @pluskid @freddycct together. Currently my design is: we take a mask as an input for each step. which is like The computation cost is similar to an activation, and with this we can easily mask out head in encoder and tail in decoder. What else I am considering is doing manual fusion of LSTM unit. I think CuDNN API may not be best choice, in case if we want to use sub-linear tech to reduce RNN memory. If we can make an op of LSTM, which takes input `[data, h, c, mask]`, and output `[h, c]`, and internally we manually fusion activation and mask, it will be much flexible than CuDNN, and should not be that slow than CuDNN.

- [ ] Multi-Input Support #1269 #2266 
- [ ] Sparse Matrix Input Support #1524 #2902 
- [x] Make the model object can be saved in RDS format

@antinucleon: I agree that the inability to use sub-linear memory techniques is a major limitation of cuDNN at the moment. But it does seem likely that they will add a 'low-memory' mode (implementing some version of https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.03401.pdf or https://arxiv.org/abs/1604.06174)  in a future release (like they do with convolution). 

Have you managed to perform timings of your fused LSTM against cuDNN? And I assume this is being done at the binding language level?

I think it is hard for Cudnn to implement the sublinear, as Cudnn is only
able to do sublinear for one layer, and the internal [h] will be saved for
next layer.

So I assume it will lead to a diverge of API: Cudnn one and a single graph
one

I don't do the manual fusion yet. From perf figure they released,, I assume
the major difference comes from fusion. But you are right we need to make
it happen first.

@Maratyszcza: you are correct, DAAL does indeed call MKL (I didn't know this). [But](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/opendaal):

> Previous versions of Intel DAAL required separate installation of the Intel Math Kernel Library (Intel MKL) and Intel Integrated Performance Primitives (Intel IPP). The latest version of Intel DAAL actually comes with the necessary binary parts of Intel MKL (for BLAS and LAPACK) as well as Intel IPP (compression and decompression)

So DAAL is similar to cuDNN, the implementation is not open source, but comes with permissive license to use. I will will correct this above. Also, you are right, we should probably use MKL directly (unless perhaps the license for DAAL is much more permissive?)

Also, DAAL is not similar to MXNet. It was designed to be useable from other frameworks, [for example](https://software.intel.com/en-us/forums/intel-data-analytics-acceleration-library/topic/671566):

> Intel DAAL has a flexible API that allows to make integration to deep learning frameworks on different levels. It is possible, for example, to replace the implementation of a particular layer of neural network by DAAL implementation, or to replace the group of layers, or to feed the model trained with Caffe, Theano or Torch as an input to scoring stage of neural network implemented with DAAL.
@antinucleon: with cuDNN, you can specify the number of layers you want. Why can't they do sublinear for this stack of layers?

Thanks for correct me. I need to check CuDNN API again. However, during
experiment of sublinear, we find out that even if we do mirror, if we keep
the classifier part, the memory cost reduce is not obvious. So in my mind
unless make the whole network into graph, sublinear is not that efficient.

@antinucleon: interesting, but I do wonder how much more memory can be squeezed out when you are writing things in CUDA, rather than just being able to do mirrors on certain nodes of the computational graph.

Also, for interest:
1. Blog post on optimizations cuDNN has done: https://devblogs.nvidia.com/parallelforall/optimizing-recurrent-neural-networks-cudnn-5/
2. One major optimization I'm looking forward to cuDNN supporting in the future: http://svail.github.io/persistent_rnns/ + https://github.com/baidu-research/persistent-rnn

I think with async execution engine, we are doing similar thing.

After we fuse the element wise op, the main difference will be more Cuda
calls than Cudnn.

So I think we may diverge API, provide Cudnn RNN and RNN. RNN for our fused
unit.

@antinucleon: ok, interesting that you are working on something like this.

Also, we should decide whether to add mask support to the cudnn RNN symbol. It actually supports variable length sequences (as long as they are sorted in order of sequence length). We can have exactly the same interface that you propose (`[data, h, c, mask]`, and `output [h, c]`).

Sounds great. If we are sure mask is able to fix most of possible problem,
we may consider to add mask as default input.

This is how I use your lstm in my lstm_unroll

```
    data  = mx.sym.Variable('data')
    label = mx.sym.Variable('label')
    mask  = mx.sym.Variable('mask')

    # (batch, time, vec) so axis 1 is the time step

    embed = mx.sym.Embedding(
        data=data, input_dim=num_labels,
        weight=embed_weight, output_dim=num_hidden, name='embed'
    )
    wordvec = mx.sym.SliceChannel(data=embed, num_outputs=enc_len + dec_len, squeeze_axis=1)
    masks   = mx.sym.SliceChannel(data=mask,  num_outputs=enc_len + dec_len, squeeze_axis=1)

    hidden_all = []
    for seqidx in range(enc_len + dec_len):
        hidden = wordvec[seqidx]
        mask_in = masks[seqidx]

        # stack LSTM
        for i in range(num_lstm_layer):
            dp = 0.0 if i == 0 else dropout

            # encoder RNN
            next_state = lstm(
                num_hidden,
                indata     = hidden,
                mask       = mask_in,
                prev_state = last_states[i],
                param      = enc_param_cells[i] if seqidx < enc_len else dec_param_cells[i],
                seqidx     = seqidx,
                layeridx   = i,
                dropout    = dp
            )
```

There is a [branch ](https://github.com/Godricly/mxnet/tree/DTypeBN)under my mxnet.If you are only using cuDNN BN, it should be good enough to start with.
- It is functional with cuDNN. But not with the native mshadow one. 
- The cudnn BN of FP16 is using float for mean and variance. I haven't figure out how to get infer_type compatible both with and without cuDNN. The marco I used will break non-cuDNN version.

Considering these two issues, I didn't submit it.
